Students will present the first steps of their case study analysis in a short presentation to their peers in a tutorial.


Students will have the opportunity to present and discuss their findings with their peers, as part of the process of completing their final case study project. They will also receive written feedback from their tutor about their presentation and what they might need to improve in developing their final project.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8ec2453bdb391c50eb6b147a3a96196a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e5c2453bdb391c50eb6b147a3a96192e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"3000 word Case Study","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Each student will be required to choose a policy issue as a case study, and then track that issue through the government decision making process. They will be required to identify expert opinion, bureaucratic policy advice, stakeholder views, lobbyist interventions, state govt views, media coverage, the impact of party politics, electoral politics and ideology in Cabinet decision making, and finally the competing views in the Senate and any High Court interventions. Their task will be to identify which players and what factors shaped the final policy outcome. Students will document thier findings in a 2,500 word project.


Students will receive extensive written feedback on their project.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"cac2453bdb391c50eb6b147a3a96196d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f5c2453bdb391c50eb6b147a3a961950","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZHSS3434.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.keywords: humanities & social sciences,australian politics,public policy
contentlets.description:
This course gives students an applied, hands on, understanding of how the Australian political system works and how government policy making works in practice.

The course takes a case study approach where students are required to pick an issue they care about and to follow it through the political decision making process. As we introduce each element of the political system, the student can see how it works in practice through their case study. Students are also required to engage with their peers' case studies giving them a breadth of insight into the major issues on the Australian political landscape and the different political dynamics that develop around different issues.
contentlets.title: Australia: Who really holds power?

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZHSS3435","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS3435 - Contemporary Security Studies","description":"

This course is designed to introduce students to contemporary security studies through a critical exploration of theory and practice. Traditionally, studies in international security have assumed that states are the primary actors in world politics and that the focus of security should be concentrated on conventional military threats. Contemporary security studies challenges both assumptions. The course evaluates debates between conventional and critical security studies by exploring how security is an essentially contested concept and examining this proposition in terms of the importance of non-military issues and non-state actors. The main schools of thought are reviewed to develop conceptual tools that will be used to analyse a range of non-traditional security issues such as energy security, environmental security, ethnic conflict and health security.This is followed by a survey of non-state actors such as private security companies, non-governmental organisations, AI/robotics and multinational corporations. Students completing this course will develop their analytical skills required for understanding complex security dynamics.

This course provides a comprehensive introduction to global environmental security. It considers the sources and consequences of major environmental threats and risks such as climate change, biodiversity loss, and competition for natural resources, and analyses their geopolitical, human security, military and ecological implications. It has a dual frame that introduces conceptual approaches and debates about security and the Anthropocene, along with the challenge of framing national policy and global governance responses.

1000 words. Questions focus on eliciting analytical engagement with either a) major theoretical or philosophical questions around environmental security, the Anthropocene, or the human relationship to nature; or b) major global governance regimes relating to climate, the environment and international security

Online comment and essay margins

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS3437 - Politics of the USA","description":"

The United States is the world's superpower, and political decisions made by the US often have global ramifications. The US is also Australia's most important ally, with whom we have close strategic and defence ties.  This course will enable students to develop a strong understanding of the political system in the US.  It will examine the foundations of US politics, the role of key political institutions, and consider how power and influence functions within the system.  It will also explore areas of foreign policy and foreign relations.  Finally, the course will analyse a selection of contemporary issues and challenges faced by the US in the twenty-first century.

The United Nations (UN) has been central to global politics and world order since it was first established in the immediate aftermath of the Second World War to prevent another devastating war, and its responsibilities and activities today span many of the most pressing global security and development challenges. This course examines the past, present and future of the UN, focusing on how it shapes and is, in turn, shaped by broader global forces. It introduces students to the basic history, organisation and functions of the world organisation; it undertakes a critical survey of the efforts of the UN to prevent war, protect human rights and promote development; and it engages with key debates about how the UN may be reformed to remain relevant in a rapidly changing world.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9b8589ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a961983","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Long essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

A 2500 words essay analysing the strengths and weaknesses of the UN as a vehicle for resolving major global problems and proposing key reform measures for improving its performance. Students will receive written feedback on their essay within two weeks of submission.

Contrary to the prediction of modernisation theory, Islam is a fast-growing religion in the world. Understanding of Islam, Muslim societies and identity politics is increasingly becoming important for professional life of our graduates. This course examines contemporary challenges faced by Muslim communities with a focus on Indonesia, the largest Muslim population country in the world and regional perspectives. It introduces fundamental knowledge of Muslim religious beliefs and practices, and their historical development. It also explores the relations between Muslim communities and the state, and examines the challenging contexts in which Muslims have been placed to negotiate their identity and Islamic ideas.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS3502 - Civil-State-Military Relations in Indonesia","description":"

This course will critically analyse areas in which Indonesian people demonstrate their capacity to empowering civil society to reinforce their citizenship amidst the crucial democratic transition the nation has ever experienced. In particular, the future of Indonesia along the path of democracy, a success or a failure, would be determined by conditions in civil-state/military relations. The course will look into the practices of the state and the armed forces in relation to civil society activism, the everyday life, the practice of media, the political expressions in popular culture to assess the contemporary state of civil-state-military relations in Indonesia. The use of selected texts in Indonesian language may be used to allow students to gain an advanced understanding of the current state of democracy in Indonesia.


Topics that are covered for this course, among others, are the state ideology, Indonesian armed forces (e.g. history, doctrine, culture, etc.), social activism, as well as political expression in popular culture and media.

contentlets.keywords: humanities & social sciences,indonesia,civil-military relations in indonesia
contentlets.description:
This course will critically analyse areas in which Indonesian people demonstrate their capacity to empowering civil society to reinforce their citizenship amidst the crucial democratic transition the nation has ever experienced. In particular, the future of Indonesia along the path of democracy, a success or a failure, would be determined by conditions in civil-state/military relations. The course will look into the practices of the state and the armed forces in relation to civil society activism, the everyday life, the practice of media, the political expressions in popular culture to assess the contemporary state of civil-state-military relations in Indonesia. The use of selected texts in Indonesian language may be used to allow students to gain an advanced understanding of the current state of democracy in Indonesia.

Topics that are covered for this course, among others, are the state ideology, Indonesian armed forces (e.g. history, doctrine, culture, etc.), social activism, as well as political expression in popular culture and media.
contentlets.title: Civil-State-Military Relations in Indonesia

This course is intended for students undertaking the BA (Hons) program.  It involves the initial preparatory work for the production of a dissertation of up to 18,000 words. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"80517c7bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961936","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

The candidate will make a brief oral presentation on his/her thesis proposal in the first half of the semester.  This presentation will be attended by interested members of academic staff.


Feedback will be provided by:

a.  those attending the seminar in the form of questions and commentary.

b.  by the candidate's supervisor following the presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0c517c7bdb751c50eb6b147a3a96192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"48517c7bdb751c50eb6b147a3a96192f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"80517c7bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"84517c7bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"cc517c7bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"37417c7bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961911","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Bibliography","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"75","description":"

This consist of the production of an annotated bibliography, presenting the relevant source materials for the candidate's chosen topic.


The supervisor will provide written and oral commentary on this bibliography.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"80517c7bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"84517c7bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"cc517c7bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"fb417c7bdb751c50eb6b147a3a96190c","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZHSS4001.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2b413c7bdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thesis","assessment_type":{"label":"Attendance","value":"attendance"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"100","description":"

The thesis will be double marked.  The examiners' written reports will be made available to the candidate.

This course is intended for students undertaking the BA (Hons) program.  It involves study at advanced level of key concepts and thinkers in the Humanities and the Social Sciences.  Depending on demand and the nature of student enrollments in the degree, the course will be tailored to particular disciplinary needs, in that it may have a particular English, Geography, Indonesian studies or International and Political Studies focus or may be more broadly interdisciplinary in its focus.

A major research essay on a topic determined in consultation between course convener and the student, the consulation including formulation of topic, discussion of sources, critique of theoretical, and methodological approach.

 

Written feedback on submitted work.

In line with the School of Humanities and Social Sciences' Honours policy, this major assessment task will be double marked.

This course is intended for History students undertaking the BA (Hons) program. It involves the initial preparatory work for the production of a dissertation of up to 18,000 words. Admission to Honours in History is at the discretion of the Head of School. Interested students should contact the School Administrator within HASS. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1ff6fc3bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961906","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Bibliography","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"75","description":"

This consist of the production of an annotated bibliography, presenting the relevant source materials for the candidate's chosen topic.


The supervisor will provide written and oral commentary on this bibliography.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"13f6fc3bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961903","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8ff6bc3bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619de","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"cbf6bc3bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619e1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bef6bc3bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619d0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

The candidate will make a brief oral presentation on his/her thesis proposal in the first half of the semester.  This presentation will be attended by interested members of academic staff.


Feedback will be provided by:

a.  those attending the seminar in the form of questions and commentary.

b.  by the candidate's supervisor following the presentation.

This course is the final component of the History Honours dissertation.  It consists of a thesis of no more than 18,000 words.  Students will also be expected to present a brief oral report on their thesis progress during this semester.  The project will be supervised by one or more members of academic staff.

This course  reflects systematically on different theoretical and methodological approaches to the discipline, and perspectives on the nature of historical knowledge. 


This course is intended for History students undertaking the BA (Hons) program. It involves advanced coursework to be determined by the Head of School. Admission to Honours in History is at the discretion of the Head of School. Interested students should contact the School Administrator within HASS.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4e4dd97fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961935","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay (3500 words)","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will be required either to analyse critically two or more major pieces of historical writing on the basis of the concepts  studied during the course, or to evaluate and compare the relevance and limitations of two historical approaches or ‘schools’ for the study of particular historical phenomena

This course is intended for History students undertaking the BA (Hons) program. It involves advanced coursework to be determined by the Head of School. Admission to Honours in History is at the discretion of the Head of School. Interested students should contact the School Administrator within HASS.

This course is intended for History students undertaking the BA (Hons) program. It involves advanced coursework to be determined by the Head of School. Admission to Honours in History is at the discretion of the Head of School. Interested students should contact the School Administrator within HASS.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3122c9b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961903","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Operational plan (3000 words, plus performance)","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be required to draft a detailed operational plan to set in any period of the war. A start date must be determined for this operation and it must be based on a factual understanding of the forces that existed at that time as well as their respective strengths (these must be set out). The student must establish obtainable operational and strategic parameters for the offensive and explain in detail how these will be achieved. The plan should involve at least one large (A3) map (hand drawn is fine) and will have to be defended against critical assessments. Presentations must last about 15 minutes and not more than 20 minutes.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"352289b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7d2289b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b92289b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f52289b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6d2289b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619e8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay(4000 words)","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Students will be required to research an essay using as much primary material as possible to represent a German or Soviet operation in World War II. The idea here is to provide a clear understanding of the progress and development of these events in relation to the wider war aims and strategic objectives (or lack thereof) of the protagonist.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7d2289b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b92289b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a52289b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZHSS4008.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This course is one of two coursework components of the fourth year honours program in International & Political Studies. It builds on students' previous studies in IPS by requiring students to reflect on Australian grand strategy: what goals do our leaders aim for and how do they use the instruments of statecraft to attain these goals? The course assumes that student have completed an IPS major.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2da2cdf7db391c50eb6b147a3a961996","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

An essay on a topic determined in consultation between course convener and the student. Worth 40% of the total marks. 

Detailed consultation prior to submission (formulation of topic, discussion of sources, critique of theoretical and/or methodological approach)

 

Written feedback on submitted work.

In line with the School of Humanities and Social Sciences' Honours policy, all work at this level is double marked.

This course is one of two coursework components of the fourth year honours program in English and Media Studies. It is intended to extend students' previous learning in English and Media studies by developing their knowledge of a specific area within the study of anglophone traditions of literature and film. The course assumes that students have completed an English and Media Studies major.

This course is intended for Indonesian Studies students undertaking the BA (Hons) program. It involves study at advanced level of key concepts and thinkers in Indonesian Studies and/or Southeast Asian Studies. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4c8249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619bb","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"75","description":"

A major research essay on a topic determined in consultation between course convener and the student.

Detailed consultation prior to submission (formulation of topic, discussion of sources, critique of theoretical and/or methodological approach)

Written feedback on submitted work.

In line with the School of Humanities and Social Sciences' Honours policy, all work at this level is double marked.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"008249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"048249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"408249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b77249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f37249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b77249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961992","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Bibliography","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

This consist of the production of an annotated bibliography, presenting the relevant source materials for the candidate's chosen topic.

Whichever necessary, students may be assessed for the translation skill when working with texts written in non-English speaking language (i.e. Indonesian, Malays)

The supervisor will provide written and oral commentary on this bibliography.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"408249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b77249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f37249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ff7249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961996","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZHSS4011.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This course allows students who have


a)      previously completed at least 12 days of approved professional education short courses in topics relevant to the degree program, or


b)      who have engaged in professional education research activities in topics relevant to the degree program and of a standard and extent approved by the Program Authority, or


c)       who have developed significant relevant knowledge in topics relevant to the degree program, and of a standard approved by the Program Authority, through a mix of professional experience and professional education,


 


to gain recognition for that learning. They must prepare an essay in approved form demonstrating their understanding of those issues and the relationship of that learning to the program's objectives, as well as a portfolio summarizing the relevant professional learning in a), b) or c) above.


The course is only available to students in selected Masters programs and, unless specified as a core or elective course within a program, will be counted as one of the two out of program electives allowed in the program.

contentlets.keywords: humanities & social sciences,professional practice
contentlets.description:
This course allows students who have

a)      previously completed at least 12 days of approved professional education short courses in topics relevant to the degree program, or

b)      who have engaged in professional education research activities in topics relevant to the degree program and of a standard and extent approved by the Program Authority, or

c)       who have developed significant relevant knowledge in topics relevant to the degree program, and of a standard approved by the Program Authority, through a mix of professional experience and professional education,

 

to gain recognition for that learning. They must prepare an essay in approved form demonstrating their understanding of those issues and the relationship of that learning to the program's objectives, as well as a portfolio summarizing the relevant professional learning in a), b) or c) above.

The course is only available to students in selected Masters programs and, unless specified as a core or elective course within a program, will be counted as one of the two out of program electives allowed in the program.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ZHSS8106","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8106 - War and Memory","description":"

This course will introduce students to the key concepts from the booming field of memory studies that allow us to explain why debates about the past can be so heated – what is at stake in these discussions? What enables, and indeed compels, us to “remember” conflicts that we did not experience personally? What are the ethical limits of such memorialisation? How do memories change across time? And what is “forgotten” in this process? In pursuit of answers to these and many other questions, we will pair our theoretical readings with a range of materials that memorialise some of the key moments of the 20th and 21st centuries, for example: the First World War; the Holocaust; the Cold War; and the recent conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan. Materials studied may include novels, memoirs, anthologies of soldiers’ writings, documentaries, feature films and websites.

This is a single session, 12 UOC course based on the development and completion of a research project. The prerequisite for entry is a Distinction average across four courses. The research topic will be of relevance to and counted towards the Masters program in which the student is enrolled and will be agreed in consultation with a supervisor as a Course Coordinator, and approved by the Program Authority. Applicants should approach a potential supervisor or the Course Authority with a brief research proposal. The length of the research project will be 10,000 – 12,000 words. The aim of the course is to allow students to deepen their understanding of a topic and develop critical thinking and independent research and writing skills in order to improve their prospects of acceptance into research degree programs.

This is a full year, 12 UOC course of study based on the development and completion of a research project. The prerequisite for entry is a Distinction average across four courses. Students must enrol in the course in two successive semesters (6 UOC each semester). The research topic will be of relevance to and counted towards the Masters program in which the student is enrolled and will be agreed in consultation with a supervisor as a Course Coordinator, and approved by the Program Authority. Applicants should approach a potential supervisor or the Course Authority with a brief research proposal. The length of the research project will be 10,000 – 12,000 words. The aim of the course is to allow students to deepen their understanding of a topic and develop critical thinking and independent research and writing skills in order to improve their prospects of acceptance into research degree programs.

contentlets.keywords: humanities & social sciences
contentlets.description: This is a full year, 12 UOC course of study based on the development and completion of a research project. The prerequisite for entry is a Distinction average across four courses. Students must enrol in the course in two successive semesters (6 UOC each semester). The research topic will be of relevance to and counted towards the Masters program in which the student is enrolled and will be agreed in consultation with a supervisor as a Course Coordinator, and approved by the Program Authority. Applicants should approach a potential supervisor or the Course Authority with a brief research proposal. The length of the research project will be 10,000 – 12,000 words. The aim of the course is to allow students to deepen their understanding of a topic and develop critical thinking and independent research and writing skills in order to improve their prospects of acceptance into research degree programs.
contentlets.title: Research Project - English and Media Studies Full Year

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8125 - Strategic Communication","description":"

This course is about the power of words, stories and images to inform, persuade, unite and divide. Studying a range of theories and a small number of case studies, we ask: What is the potential for narratives to serve as rallying points for social groups? How do these groups adapt these narratives and the institutions which maintain them according to changing needs and concerns? What constitutes offence on the page, and how might communication be strategically suppressed as a result? How are old and new communication technologies put to use in the battle of narratives? Materials studied may include political treatises, propaganda posters, novels, documentaries, feature films, anthologies of soldiers’ writings, and various forms of Social Media.

We will study navies and sea power in the modern world, from the 1890s to the present, concentrating on various thematic issues. The approach will be international, with a focus on the major naval powers. Themes will include how far classical arguments for sea power remain valid, how far there are naturally naval and continental powers and national naval strategic traditions, how far navies have special capabilities, and modern naval and maritime strategic ideas.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8210 - Genocide: Perception and Intervention","description":"

This course studies genocide in the twentieth century and focuses on the challenges faced by the international community after the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide. Students will begin by exploring the scholarly and legal difficulties of definition. They will analyse the major cases of genocide in the two world wars, Cambodia, the former Yugoslavia, Rwanda and Dafur as well as questions of genocide within other and contexts. In particular, the course will focus on several issues: difficulties of perception and recognition; the role of various international agencies and major powers; international relations and strategic limitations that determine the timing and nature of intervention; and the problems of punishment.

contentlets.description: This course studies genocide in the twentieth century and focuses on the challenges faced by the international community after the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide. Students will begin by exploring the scholarly and legal difficulties of definition. They will analyse the major cases of genocide in the two world wars, Cambodia, the former Yugoslavia, Rwanda and Dafur as well as questions of genocide within other and contexts. In particular, the course will focus on several issues: difficulties of perception and recognition; the role of various international agencies and major powers; international relations and strategic limitations that determine the timing and nature of intervention; and the problems of punishment.

This is a single session, 12 UOC course based on the development and completion of a research project. The research topic will be of relevance to and counted towards the Masters program in which the student is enrolled and will be agreed in consultation with a supervisor as a Course Coordinator, and approved by the Program Authority. The prerequisite for entry is a Distinction average across four courses. Applicants should approach a potential supervisor or the Course Authority with a brief research proposal. The length of the research project will be 10,000 – 12,000 words. The aim of the course is to allow students to deepen their understanding of a topic and develop critical thinking and independent research and writing skills in order to improve their prospects of acceptance into research degree programs.

Assessment for this course is one research essay of 10,000 - 12,000 words, which is 100% of the assessment. The course coordinator/supervisor will schedule research and writing milestones and give regular feedback to the student throughout the session and on completion of the essay.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ZHSS8215","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8215 - Research Project: History - Full Year","description":"

This is a full year, 12 UOC course of study based on the development and completion of a research project. The prerequisite for entry is a Distinction average across four courses. Students must enrol in the course in two successive semesters (6 UOC each semester). The research topic will be of relevance to and counted towards the Masters program in which the student is enrolled and will be agreed in consultation with a supervisor as a Course Coordinator, and approved by the Program Authority. Applicants should approach a potential supervisor or the Course Authority with a brief research proposal. The length of the research project will be 10,000 – 12,000 words. The aim of the course is to allow students to deepen their understanding of a topic and develop critical thinking and independent research and writing skills in order to improve their prospects of acceptance into research degree programs.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1ddb29f3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96193d","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"100","description":"

Assessment for this course is one research essay of 10,000 - 12,000 words, which is 100% of the assessment. The course coordinator/supervisor will schedule research and writing milestones and give regular feedback to the student throughout the session and on completion.

This course will give the student an overall understanding of the military history and the historiographical debates of the Second World War. Students will analyse the strategic decisions, major air, sea and land campaigns and the key turning points of the military struggle in the three major theatres of Western Europe, the Eastern Front and the Pacific.

contentlets.keywords: humanities & social sciences,political economy of warfare,logistics and business of war,role and impract of technology,battle in cultural context and perspective
contentlets.description: This course provides an introductory survey of the major themes and developments in the field of Military History from the Classical world onwards. Themes addressed include the influence of technology, development of armies, the existence or otherwise of a 'Western way of war', logistics, the relationships between strategy and tactics, and the experience of battle.
contentlets.title: The Development of the Art of War: A Survey

contentlets.keywords: humanities & social sciences,origins of first world war
contentlets.description: This course examines the major themes and developments in the First World War, 1914-19. It considers all major, and some lesser, theatres of the war and introduces students to the major historiographical arguments concerning these in a vast and rich historical literature.
contentlets.title: The First World War 1914-1919

contentlets.description: This course examines the theory and practice of small wars and insurgencies in colonial and some post-colonial contexts from the 18th century to the present. The course takes a case study approach to the subject, and will draw on examples from across the European colonial experience.
contentlets.title: Small Wars of Empire: Colonial Warfare from 1700

This course offers an introduction to the role and impact of war upon the development of Australia. It deals with settler-indigenous conflict, the world two wars, the post-1945 conflicts in our region, developments in defence policy in periods of peace, and commitments in a variety of theatres since the early 1990s.

contentlets.keywords: humanities & social sciences,war in indochina,french colonial rule 1945
contentlets.description: This course examines the causes, course and consequences of the wars in Indochina from the return of French colonial rule in 1945 to the defeat of American and allied interests in 1975 with the fall of Saigon and the end of the Republic of Vietnam. The course will introduce students to a number of major historiographical arguments within the extensive and diverse historical literature on the war.
contentlets.title: The Vietnam Wars: A Thirty Year Conflict

A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ZHSS8227","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8227 - Civil Wars: Societies in Conflict","description":"

Civil wars are inherently complex and hard to define, spanning wars of national liberation, insurgency, and succession as well as political and social violence involving non-state actors in weak, fragile or failed states. The real determinants of violence are often overlapping, including ethnic and religious division, economic inequalities, class, social or political exclusion, and competition for scarce natural resources. Drawing on a selection of case studies from different historical periods and regions, this course investigates the dynamics and drivers of civil wars, the course and conduct of particular conflicts including the strategies used by armed factions to sustain conflict, and their localised and international impact.

Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ZHSS8230","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8230 - Russian Military History","description":"

The course aims to introduce students to Russian military history and provide them with a solid starting point, as well as the necessary skills, to research and critically consider this field of study. There is no assumed subject knowledge in the topic itself or the Russian language, but as a postgraduate course students will be expected to have competent academic research and writing skills.


The main aim of the course is to gain an appreciation of the complex and reciprocal relationship between war, the military and Russian society throughout the early modern and modern periods. There will be scope for discussion of individual campaigns and battles, but these must be seen against tends in both the Russian and global context of warfare. The early modern 'Military Revolution', the industrialization of warfare and concept of 'Total War' would all be potential examples of locating and exploring the Russian military experience in a wider context. The aim is to introduce students to a wide body of literature without the focus on Russia becoming a vacuum. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"489bb877dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ba","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"MAJOR ESSAY","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

The topic for the major essay can come from any of the periods covered in the course and should allow students to build on their readings and work from literature review. The students will be expected to access and discuss primary material as part of their research. They will be provided with reading lists for each topic of available works in English. The major essay brings together the skills of the course and will be expected to show serious research and critical engagement with the selected topic. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"089bb877dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"449bb877dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4c9bb877dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"809bb877dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96199b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3f8bb877dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961966","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"LITERATURE REVIEW","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

This assignment is designed to get people thinking about and engaging with the historiography for their major essay. Students are required to select a reading indicated in the ‘further reading’ lists for each topic and write a critical review of the article or selected book chapter. I am not seeking a simple summary of the material, but how this work contributes to, or differs from, the wider historiography in this field. Students are therefore expected to look at a number of articles/chapters to allow context and show critical engagement.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4c9bb877dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"809bb877dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96199b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bb8bb877dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96195d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"CAMPAIGN REVIEW","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will select a Russian/Soviet campaign from one of the periods covered by the course topics and discuss its significance in context of one of the following;

·         The social composition of the rank and file Russian/Soviet men.

·         The Russian/Soviet application and understanding of logistics.

·         The application of military reform.

·         The application of a given technology (i.e. a new weapon, administrative aid or scientific instrument). You will need to be clear and specific about how the response to this technology impacts behaviour/events.

The campaign selected cannot come from the same topic as assignment 3 (the major essay).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"089bb877dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4c9bb877dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f38bb877dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961962","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZHSS8230.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ZHSS8231","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8231 - The History of Special Operations","description":"

This course offers a broad survey of the history of modern special operations forces, from their antecedents in the ancient, medieval and early modern world, through the formative years of the first half of the 20th Century, to the contemporary era. Particular attention is paid to the history of Australian and New Zealand special operations as well as that of close allies the United States, the United Kingdom, and Canada. It discusses what history can teach us about how and why governments decide to deploy special operations personnel, examines a range of missions by special operations forces from a variety of nations, and places the use of special operations units within the wider context of the continually evolving nature of armed conflict.

Students are required to write a focused analysis (approx. 1,500 words) critically evaluating the competing claims of two or more scholarly works related to the history of special operations.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8232 - History of Post-colonial Warfare in Africa: An Introduction","description":"

This course examines the theory and practice of wars in post-colonial Africa south of the Sahara. It adopts a case study approach, and will draw on examples from across the history of post-independence Africa. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f0fd3cfbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96191a","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will be given the opportunity to select a topic (as approved by the course coordinator) related to the course on which to write an in-depth research essay.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b4fd3cfbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b8fd3cfbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f4fd3cfbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961916","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"28fdf8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619cc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Analysis Paper 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will be required to write a focused analysis of some 1,500 words critically evaluating two overarching explanations of post-colonial warfare in Africa.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b8fd3cfbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f4fd3cfbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961916","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"60fdf8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Analysis Paper 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will be required to write a focused analysis of some 1,500 words critically evaluating the competing claims of two or more scholarly works relating to the history of warfare in Africa since independence.

\n

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8235 - Ten American Conflicts: The Origins of US Military History","description":"

From the second half of the twentieth century the United States became the world's premier military power. But how did it evolve in three centuries from isolated settlements on the Atlantic coast to a world power? How did the experience of conflicts over three centuries from 1600 shape American ways of war, on land and sea; in and beyond north America? This course will examine ten American conflicts 1607-1914 to examine the relationship between war and the European settlement of north America and those conflicts and the history of the United States, looking at both the experience and impact of those wars and their consequences and memory.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8236 - A British Way in Warfare?: Strategy and Defence Policy 1856-1945","description":"

The course examines the way in which the British Empire developed and exerted power to achieve its strategic ends. To do so it will explore the intersections between national, foreign and defence policy, and how these took shape in a coherent strategic outlook.


Throughout the period Britain was a “status quo” power having to meet the challenges of a host of new “revisionist” states seeking to undermine its position as global hegemon. The period ends with the passing of that mantle on to the United States. The course will consider how successfully British policy makers managed the challenges they faced, in both war and peace.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8237 - The Cold War","description":"

The course provides an insight into the origins, development and consequences of the Cold War—the confrontation between capitalism and socialism shaped the international system and the Asia–Pacific region and affected most of the world’s population for nearly half a century from 1945. The course charts the origins of the Cold War and its evolution, considering geopolitical, ideological, strategic, economic and sociopolitical developments. The Cold War will be examined globally with emphasis on its manifestations in the Asia–Pacific region.


 This course is a survey course designed to give students a broad introduction into the history of the Cold War as well as to build students’ skills. It will develop students’ ability to think analytically, by focusing on the different interpretations of the Cold War by both historians and historical actors.

contentlets.description:
The course provides an insight into the origins, development and consequences of the Cold War—the confrontation between capitalism and socialism shaped the international system and the Asia–Pacific region and affected most of the world’s population for nearly half a century from 1945. The course charts the origins of the Cold War and its evolution, considering geopolitical, ideological, strategic, economic and sociopolitical developments. The Cold War will be examined globally with emphasis on its manifestations in the Asia–Pacific region.

 This course is a survey course designed to give students a broad introduction into the history of the Cold War as well as to build students’ skills. It will develop students’ ability to think analytically, by focusing on the different interpretations of the Cold War by both historians and historical actors.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8238 - Australia's Relations with Asia","description":"

The course provides an insight into Australia’s political, economic, strategic and people-to-people engagement with Asia from colonial times to the present. The course discusses the impact of Chinese immigration on the Australian colonies and the origins of the White Australia policy; Australia’s incipient engagement with Asia, and particularly Japan, in the first four decades after Federation; the  effect of the Second World War and the Cold War Australia’s on relations with Asia; Australia’s engagement with Asia in the post-colonial era from 1972 to 1996; and the transformative effect on Australia of the rise of China in the period  from 1996 to the present.

contentlets.description: The course provides an insight into Australia’s political, economic, strategic and people-to-people engagement with Asia from colonial times to the present. The course discusses the impact of Chinese immigration on the Australian colonies and the origins of the White Australia policy; Australia’s incipient engagement with Asia, and particularly Japan, in the first four decades after Federation; the  effect of the Second World War and the Cold War Australia’s on relations with Asia; Australia’s engagement with Asia in the post-colonial era from 1972 to 1996; and the transformative effect on Australia of the rise of China in the period  from 1996 to the present.
contentlets.title: Australia's Relations with Asia

This is a single session, 12 UOC course based on the development and completion of a research project. The prerequisite for entry is a Distinction average accross four courses. The research topic will be of relevance to and counted towards the Masters program in which the student is enrolled and will be agreed in consultation with a supervisor as a Course Coordinator, and approved by the Program Authority. Applicants should approach a potential supervisor or the Course Authority with a brief research proposal. The length of the research project will be 10,000 – 12,000 words. The aim of the course is to allow students to deepen their understanding of a topic and develop critical thinking and independent research and writing skills in order to improve their prospects of acceptance into research degree programs.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8403 - Global Security","description":"

This course provides a detailed critical survey of key issues, theories and practices of global security in the early 21st Century. It examines the contested and changing nature of the concept of security, and surveys theoretical debates from the traditional to the cutting edge of current thinking. This course goes beyond questions of national security to take a specifically global perspective. It is especially concerned with understanding the intersection of global insecurity dynamics and global governance regimes, across a range of issue areas.

contentlets.description: This course introduces students to the institutions and techniques of global governance in an age of hyper-globalisation. It deals with the roles of non-state actors in global politics from the United Nations to the global economy to terrorist regimes.

contentlets.keywords: humanities & social sciences,asia-pacific security: order or disorder,us alliance system,regional organisations and security,china and asia-pacific security,japans regional security role,indias rise and regional security,russia and regional security,north korea nuclear crisis,south china sea disputes,new security agenda: environmental security in the asia-pacific,new security agenda: pandemics
contentlets.description: This course examines the key elements shaping the Asia-Pacific security environment in the early 21st century. It blends an understanding of the principal themes and trends that are influencing the progress of the region as a whole with detailed insights into particular nations and the strategic issues most likely to impact on its future direction and stability. Students will be encouraged to explore the main issues in depth and to identify the relationships between them and their practical implications for policy makers. Particular attention is given to analysing security flashpoints and to the new security challenges.
contentlets.title: Asia-Pacific Security: The Dynamics of Change

contentlets.keywords: humanities & social sciences,the foundations of self reliance,responding to uncertainty,the politics of alliance: managing the us relationship,dancing with elephants: australia and the major powers,engaging the immediate region: relations with se asia,crisis in paradise?: australia and the south pacific,from denial to preemption: options for defence strategy
contentlets.description: This course provides an in-depth understanding of the dynamics of Australia's strategic and defence policy and the challenges that it is facing in both determining priorities and bridging the gap between desired ends and available means. It examines how the current policies have evolved, the factors that will determine their future shape, and the options available for resolving current and prospective dilemmas. Attention is given to the balance between defence of Australia tasks and broader security commitments, to the tools for producing sustainable capacity (personnel, equipment and national support), and to the complexities of managing security relations with others.
contentlets.title: Australian Defence Policy: Concepts and Challenges

contentlets.keywords: humanities & social sciences,war in the air,emerging security environment,21st century challenges
contentlets.description: What roles can air power play in the diverse types of operations undertaken for national security: wars, anti-terrorism, stabilisation and humanitarian missions? How can a flexible and responsive air power capacity be developed within strict resource and political constraints? What is the role of air power in the new security environment? How can air power contribute to national security in a whole-of-government approach? How can a strategic air force be developed? What are the challenges of joint operations with other services or in coalition with other defence forces? These are among the strategic and policy issues examined in this course.
contentlets.title: Air Power in the 21st Century: Strategic Issues

contentlets.keywords: humanities & social sciences,military modernisation and doctrinal changes,civil-military,china's security policy
contentlets.description: This course introduces students to Chinaâ??s security policy and the post-Mao military modernisation program. Chinaâ??s security concerns, its evolving security strategy and rapidly growing military capacity will be assessed. Particular attention will be paid to the current academic and policy debate on Chinaâ??s growing military power and evolving strategic policies. The course will explore shifts in the Peopleâ??s Liberation Armyâ??s threat perceptions, strategic doctrine, force structure, civil-military relations, military technology and defence industry. Chinaâ??s strategic culture and its impact on military thinking will also be assessed.
contentlets.title: China's Security Policy and Military Modernisation

This course provides an in-depth understanding of the issues and challenges that are shaping decisions to use military force in the 21st century. It examines the breadth and characteristics of the diverse range of conflict situations and MOOTW into which forces might be deployed and considers both the international and domestic issues that would need to be addressed in making a decision to do so. It addresses the lessons learnt from recent operations. Consideration is also given to the specific factors determining the roles which military forces might undertake, the selection of appropriate capabilities and how operations are conducted.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8437 - Global Justice and World Politics","description":"

Some of the most serious and vexing moral and political dilemmas of our time are global rather than national.  These include issues such as world poverty, migration and refugees, climate change, failed and failing states, and so on. What, if anything, should we do about these problems? And why? This course examines issues such as these, and asks who - whether particular states, international organisations or individuals - should ultimately be responsible for trying to fix them.

contentlets.keywords: humanities & social sciences
contentlets.description: Some of the most serious and vexing moral and political dilemmas of our time are global rather than national.  These include issues such as world poverty, migration and refugees, climate change, failed and failing states, and so on. What, if anything, should we do about these problems? And why? This course examines issues such as these, and asks who - whether particular states, international organisations or individuals - should ultimately be responsible for trying to fix them.
contentlets.title: Global Justice and World Politics

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8438 - The Justice of War: States, Self-Defence & Force","description":"

Militarism glorifies war. Pacifism condemns it absolutely. Just War Theory treats war as an evil, but one that is sometimes necessary and morally defensible. So when is a state justified in resorting to military force? Traditionally, Just War theorists have maintained that only national self-defence against aggression constitutes a just cause. More recently this view has come under critical pressure. Some contemporary Just War thinkers see the traditional view as too permissive insofar as it licences the use of force - and the death and destruction attendant thereupon - in response to any breach of political sovereignty or territorial integrity. Others see the traditional paradigm as too restrictive insofar as it forbids both armed humanitarian intervention (the use of force to defend foreign nationals against a murderous or oppressive government), and preventive action to neutralise a threat in advance of its materialization (to eliminate WMDs, for instance). This course will provide students with a comprehensive overview of the philosophical debate over when the use of military force is morally justified.

More recently this view has come under critical pressure. Some contemporary Just War thinkers see the traditional view as too permissive insofar as it licences the use of force - and the death and destruction attendant thereupon - in response to any breach of political sovereignty or territorial integrity. Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8439 - Reforming Repressive Regimes","description":"

This course mixes broad theoretical discussions with in-depth case studies in order to shed light on the challenges involved in influencing repressive states. The first module draws on comparative politics to elucidate the internal characteristics of repressive states, including their motivations, stability and overall susceptibility to international influences. The second module surveys the international relations literatures on international influence in general, and democracy and human rights more specifically. Finally, in the third module, these general insights are combined and applied to several prominent contemporary case studies in order to evaluate different international policy options. Students will have the opportunity in class discussions and assessment essays to apply the general ideas and concepts to a variety of repressive states depending on their own interests, using general skills of policy analysis taught in the course.

contentlets.keywords: humanities & social sciences,security,democracy,human rights,violence,international statecraft,foreign policy,influence
contentlets.description: This course mixes broad theoretical discussions with in-depth case studies in order to shed light on the challenges involved in influencing repressive states. The first module draws on comparative politics to elucidate the internal characteristics of repressive states, including their motivations, stability and overall susceptibility to international influences. The second module surveys the international relations literatures on international influence in general, and democracy and human rights more specifically. Finally, in the third module, these general insights are combined and applied to several prominent contemporary case studies in order to evaluate different international policy options. Students will have the opportunity in class discussions and assessment essays to apply the general ideas and concepts to a variety of repressive states depending on their own interests, using general skills of policy analysis taught in the course.
contentlets.title: Reforming Repressive Regimes

This course introduces a conflict transformation approach to conflict and post conflict analysis. Beginning with a critical survey of the field, the course explores different approaches through consideration of protracted conflicts in contemporary global politics. Conflict transformation theory recognises the complexity of conflict dynamics (not having neat beginnings, middles and endings) and challenges the effectiveness of management and resolution approaches. A transformational approach observes that peace settlement and management strategies themselves have often been the source of deep resentment and justification for further violence. Transformation of protracted conflicts require more than the redistribution of material resources or reframing of positions into resolved outcomes. The approach builds upon a deeper analysis of identity of stakeholders, issues, historical grievances, structural factors and divergent world views. In policy terms, this approach strongly aligns with the UN Peacebuilding Commission approach.

Eight multiple choice and short answer tests for each topic in the course. Each test is worth 5%.

These quizzes refelect thje required reading and help build foundational knowldege of Conflict Analysis and Prevention Theory.

Immediate online feedback with explanations for correct and incorrect answers for M/C questions is provided.

Audio Visual (Collaborate) online presentation (7 mins) examining one of the following:

  • A Peace Treaty or;
  • A Nobel Peace Prize recipient 

The presentation should:

  • (1) briefly describe the significance of event/person;
    (2) examine and highlight elements of the treaty/award speech and,
    (3) critically evaluate the controversy, conflict surrounding the event/person
  • Please also upload slides to moodle in either ppt or pdf format.
","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7401707bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961924","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Conflict Transformation Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Write a 2500 word conflict transformation report that seeks to understand the deeper context of a protracted conflict.*

Drawing upon the conceptual themes addressed in this course, the analysis should follow the conflict mapping approach outlined in the textbook (Ramsbotham et. al, 2016:103-4). The Conflict Map should include the following elements:

  • Who are the parties? 
  • What are the main issues of contention?
  • What are the historical grievances?
  • What are structural and contextual factors?

The Report should also carefully analyse the following:

  • What efforts at conflict prevention, settlement, containment or resolution have been attempted in the past?
  • What recommendations can you propose for conflict transformation?

* Cases can be selected from the Resources Tab in Moodle or the Textbook examples.

contentlets.keywords: humanities & social sciences,conflict analysis,conflict prevention,conflict resolution,conflict transformation
contentlets.description: This course introduces a conflict transformation approach to conflict and post conflict analysis. Beginning with a critical survey of the field, the course explores different approaches through consideration of protracted conflicts in contemporary global politics. Conflict transformation theory recognises the complexity of conflict dynamics (not having neat beginnings, middles and endings) and challenges the effectiveness of management and resolution approaches. A transformational approach observes that peace settlement and management strategies themselves have often been the source of deep resentment and justification for further violence. Transformation of protracted conflicts require more than the redistribution of material resources or reframing of positions into resolved outcomes. The approach builds upon a deeper analysis of identity of stakeholders, issues, historical grievances, structural factors and divergent world views. In policy terms, this approach strongly aligns with the UN Peacebuilding Commission approach.
contentlets.title: Conflict Transformation

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8452 - Weapons of Mass Destruction and Global Security","description":"

As events in Syria, the Ukraine, Japan, Pakistan and India over the last two decades have shown, nuclear, chemical and biological weapons remain high-level global security concerns. They are also strategically complex policy challenges, both for states and global governance. Using a mix of the best academic and policy writing, this course provides an overview of the history of weapons of mass destruction, the major control and disarmament regimes, strategic debates and doctrine,  and new perspectives on the past and future of WMDs and global security.

Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ZHSS8453","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8453 - Culture and Conflict","description":"

This course affirms the central importance of political culture, as a methodology, within the field of International and Political Studies. Understanding the complex interconnections between culture and conflict is an increasingly challenging issue for defence and security planners, and is indispensable in the context of complex operational deployments. This is nowhere more apparent than in Australia's immediate, culturally diverse, strategic environment.


Drawing upon key conceptual debates concerning political culture, students will analyse the role of culture in the causes and courses of a range of violent conflicts, past and present. The course is divided into four sections: understanding political culture and interpreting the role of culture in conflicts; seminal works and significant approaches to political culture; assumptions and misperceptions of the cultural causes of conflict and; finally, a critical evaluation of challenges that have arisen in Australia's strategic engagement and operational deployments.


Jointly convened by scholars who approach this subject from compatible but distinct fields of research, the course seeks to stimulate a lively cross-disciplinary engagement with the subject matter.  Students are encouraged to draw upon their own knowledge and experience in their analyses.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"45f4f4f3dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619d2","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Commentaries","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be required to write six brief (500 words) commentaries on the core reading for each week.  

\n

Students then select their two best commentaries and are permitted to extend them (up to 1000 words each) for submission and assessment.


Students will receive generic online feedback on their weekly commentaries and specific feedback on their submitted works.

contentlets.keywords: humanities & social sciences,political culture,conflict analysis,strategic planning,operational effectiveness,political theory,international relations
contentlets.description:
This course affirms the central importance of political culture, as a methodology, within the field of International and Political Studies. Understanding the complex interconnections between culture and conflict is an increasingly challenging issue for defence and security planners, and is indispensable in the context of complex operational deployments. This is nowhere more apparent than in Australia's immediate, culturally diverse, strategic environment.

Drawing upon key conceptual debates concerning political culture, students will analyse the role of culture in the causes and courses of a range of violent conflicts, past and present. The course is divided into four sections: understanding political culture and interpreting the role of culture in conflicts; seminal works and significant approaches to political culture; assumptions and misperceptions of the cultural causes of conflict and; finally, a critical evaluation of challenges that have arisen in Australia's strategic engagement and operational deployments.

Jointly convened by scholars who approach this subject from compatible but distinct fields of research, the course seeks to stimulate a lively cross-disciplinary engagement with the subject matter.  Students are encouraged to draw upon their own knowledge and experience in their analyses.
contentlets.title: Culture and Conflict

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8455 - Australian Cyber Diplomacy","description":"

This course provides advanced interdisciplinary study in Australia’s diplomacy and national strategies for security in cyber space. Taking the normal definition of diplomacy as the management on the international stage of all a country's cross-border interests, the course engages primarily with four questions:


- the information economy as a foundation for national welfare and security;


- privacy and personal security in cyberspace;


- strategies for national security in cyber space;


- Australian diplomacy on these issues.


The World Economic Forum, working with the Australian Industry Group, has painted a picture of Australians as good at uptake of digital technologies for social purposes but weaker at applying them in business and industry. Australia’s economic competitors are moving rapidly into higher levels of digital innovation at the same time as our leading trade partners and neighbours in Asia have unmet demand for services in the digital economy. Inside Australia, the environment for decision-making on policy for the information age is operating on narrow pathways. The picture of our digital economy is one of falling competitiveness and only medium (to low) levels of innovation. New cyber threats and capabilities are emerging on the military and espionage scenes to which Australia must adapt and respond. But the country needs a digital age strategy for its civil sector before it can have a digital military strategy. The experience levels that key decision-makers have of the IT sector do not in many cases match the nature of the diverse problems. Perhaps the Defence organisation in Australia can take something of a lead to reverse this situation in the country as a whole. But it would need to recognise at the outset that the level of expertise in Australia in military applications in this field, as in many other countries, is low. We need new foreign allies in this field. The effort will need to be multi-national, multi-sector and private-public. In grappling with the large problems of national innovation strategies and national security issues, all actors have had to confront the social and legal impacts of advanced information technologies as well. The debate over privacy and metadata laws for security surveillance is just one example of the myriad ethical questions Australia has had to confront. The course positions the student to understand better the profound influences of the new technologies, to appreciate the main policy dilemmas emerging in their exploitation, to develop the ability to undertake critical analyse of the issues, and communicate them accordingly. This course is unique in Australian universities but leading universities abroad have similar courses.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ZHSS8456","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8456 - Australia and Cyber War","description":"

This course examines the concept of cyber war. It pays special attention to the transformation of Australian military and security forces to meet new cyber security threats and to exploit new capabilities offered by cyber assets. It explores topics including: the cyber space revolution in military affairs; middle powers and their military cyber strategy; the politics of transformational change in the Australian Defence Force; national security innovation priorities; and proposals for an Australian cyber militia. In the process, students will learn to critically assess the main policy and ethical dilemmas associated with the preparation of Australian security forces for information warfare.
