Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8457 - Cyber Security in Asia","description":"



The course provides advanced interdisciplinary study into the ways in which the advent of advanced information and communications technology has influenced military strategy and operations with special reference to Asian security. It complements an existing course on Cyber Security and World Politics and a proposed new course on Transformation of Australian Security in the Information Age. The course looks first at the cases of individual major powers (USA, China, Russia, India, Japan) and a range of middle powers (Iran, Israel, UAE, North and South Korea, Pakistan, Australia).  It then looks at how the international system has responded to new dilemmas of cyberspace affecting national and international security (cyber alliances, diplomatic strategies, mass surveillance, new and old norms, role of the globalized private sector, and cross-border critical information infrastructure.)  The final section of the course deals with some of the big analytical and policy dilemmas: cyber impacts on military nuclear, terrorism and cyberspace, information ethics and highly secure computing.

It complements an existing course on Cyber Security and World Politics and a proposed new course on Transformation of Australian Security in the Information Age. The course looks first at the cases of individual major powers (USA, China, Russia, India, Japan) and a range of middle powers (Iran, Israel, UAE, North and South Korea, Pakistan, Australia).  It then looks at how the international system has responded to new dilemmas of cyberspace affecting national and international security (cyber alliances, diplomatic strategies, mass surveillance, new and old norms, role of the globalized private sector, and cross-border critical information infrastructure.)  The final section of the course deals with some of the big analytical and policy dilemmas: cyber impacts on military nuclear, terrorism and cyberspace, information ethics and highly secure computing.

This course provides advanced interdisciplinary study into the development of cyber policy in China across social, economic, political, military and technological domains. China is universally regarded as the major player alongside the United States in the future of information technologies and their beneficial or malicious uses impacting on diplomacy and international security. China wants to compete with the world’s most advanced countries in economic and military power. It knows that this depends on high-speed, innovative application of the most modern information technologies -- that China has to become a sophisticated information-based society. But does China have what it takes to get there? Are its leaders prepared to do what it takes to get there? The answer so far appears to be “not really”! This course will provide students with the tools and the opportunity to make their own assessment of the likely outcome of China’s information society ambition from a comprehensive point of view, looking at economic, political and military considerations -- and grounded in a broad ethical vision.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8459 - Special Operations: Theory and Strategic Utility","description":"

A common distinction that is made between special operations forces (SOF) and their conventional counterparts is that SOF are 'strategic' troops. But is this really so? And if so, what does it mean? This course explores the strategic utility of special operations and the forces that carry them out, and explores competing and complementary theories of special operations. Strategic theories addressed in the course focus particularly on approaches that emphasise the notion of introducing 'strategic paralysis', often most closely associated with air-power theorists like Giulio Douhet and Billy Mitchell. These are contrasted with attrition based strategies of special operations such as that proposed by James Kiras. Influential 'kinetic' theories of special operations, like that developed by William McRaven, are compared and contrasted with strategies of influence which emphasise the 'indirect approach' of special operations forces engaged in unconventional warfare.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"313f293fdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619be","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Discussion Forum Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Over the duration of the course students are required to write brief analysis papers (each not more than 250 words) of key ideas and concepts addressed in the course. The combination of analysis papers, with reflective analysis, is to be a total of not more than 1250 words.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"393f293fdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"753f293fdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ba","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f93f293fdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2d3f293fdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96198c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Drawing on the material covered in the course, and further independent research, students are required to write a 2500-word essay analysing an ongoing foreign policy challenge representing a potential opportunity for the employment of Special Operations Forces as part of a policy recommendation. Students will be provided with a list of topics drawn from the course content at Week 9, and will be provided tools and additional context.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"713f293fdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619af","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"753f293fdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ba","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bd3f293fdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f93f293fdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a93f293fdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961983","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Analysis Papers","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Over the duration of the course students are required to write an analytical paper of not more than 1000 words addressing a historic (pre-2001) Special Operations Mission (not examined in the course) against a Special Operations Theory introduced in the course.

Over the duration of the course students are required to write an analytical paper of not more than 1000 words addressing a contemporary (post-2001) Special Operations Mission (not examined in the course) against a Special Operations Theory introduced in the course. Examination of this case should consider critical analysis of the robustness of SO Theory in today’s context.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"713f293fdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619af","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"753f293fdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ba","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f93f293fdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e13f293fdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961988","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZHSS8459.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ZHSS8460","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8460 - Power and Australian Government Policy","description":"

This subject takes an innovative approach to teaching an analytically rigorous and applied understanding of Australian politics  that makes the most of the online format. In the first half of the course students will be introduced to the institutions of Australian government and to theories of power and government decision making.


 In the second half of the course students will be required choose an issue they care about as a case study. They will track that issue through the government decision making process, with view to identifying who sought to influence the outcome and who succeeded. Students will present their case studies to each other for feedback and debate. At the end of the semester they will have intimate knowledge of their own case study, they will also have been exposed to more than a dozen other case studies. Students will gain a rich and applied sense of how the Australian government works in practice.

Students will conduct an analysis of competing stakeholders accounts of the political problem and how it should be solved.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"102b513bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d02b513bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"082b513bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Journal of Forum Posts","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Students will be required to make posts applying theories of power and government decision making to their colleagues case studies, and collate them into a journal to be submitted for assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"502b513bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d02b513bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"402b513bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Case Study Part 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will present their case study to their peers, including a powerpoint, podcast and transcript.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"102b513bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d02b513bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"882b513bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ba","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Background Institutional Knowledge Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

The background institutional knowledge modules will be revision for most students who have learnt this material at school and in first year undergraduate politics courses. They entail watching a video and completing a quiz on the material covered in the video. This is a selfpaced module that needs to be completed within the first four weeks of semester.

Students with a limited background in Australian politics will have an opportunity to log onto the Moodle site early and begin working through the background institutional knowledge modules before semester begins. Additional reading materials are provided for further explanation where required.

They will track that issue through the government decision making process, with view to identifying who sought to influence the outcome and who succeeded. Conventional Warfare, or warfare by convention, is the dominant Western approach to converting tactical military action into strategic and political ends and is challenged by irregular forms of warfare at the strategic level. Western tactical dominance has encouraged the adoption of irregular approaches to generating strategic effect. This course explores the employment of irregular warfare strategies and the forces that carry them out. In so doing, it implicitly aims to assist a Western force in developing counters to such threats. This course forms a core course for the Masters in Special Operations / Irregular Warfare, and is an elective in the Strategy and Security and War Studies programs.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5f03cd3bdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

All students are expected to both contribute to the success of the course and to engage and learn from all of its aspects. At the end of the course each student will be asked to package together his or her five forum contributions (one each is desirable from respective sections). Each student will be assessed on the level of engagement with and understanding of the topics; the engagement with and responses to questions raised (and his or her own raising of questions); and reflections on his or her own learning and intellectual development. Obviously, the preparation for this assignment involves students doing the required reading for each week, forming questions, and regularly making quality contributions in the section forums. Please remember quality matters. Brief question raising and direct on-the-point posts are usually preferable to longer more verbose posts (maximum post length is 250 words).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0703cd3bdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8b03cd3bdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7203cd3bdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Drawing on the material covered in the course, and further independent research, students are required to write a 3,000-word research essay analysing an ongoing foreign policy challenge representing a challenge from insurgency, revolution or unconventional warfare to the nation- Version 2019.S1 4 state. Students will be provided with a list of topics drawn from the course content. The details of this task will be available from the commencement of the course.

Students are required to choose from a list of options for the analysis paper and submit according to the due dates for the options selected. The details of this task will be available from the commencement of the course.

contentlets.keywords: humanities & social sciences,special operations,unconventional warfare,defence policy,irregular warfare
contentlets.description: Conventional Warfare, or warfare by convention, is the dominant Western approach to converting tactical military action into strategic and political ends and is challenged by irregular forms of warfare at the strategic level. Western tactical dominance has encouraged the adoption of irregular approaches to generating strategic effect. This course explores the employment of irregular warfare strategies and the forces that carry them out. In so doing, it implicitly aims to assist a Western force in developing counters to such threats. This course forms a core course for the Masters in Special Operations / Irregular Warfare, and is an elective in the Strategy and Security and War Studies programs.
contentlets.title: GRIM Threats (Guerrilla, Revolutionary, Insurgent and Militia) and Irregular Warfare

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ZHSS8462","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8462 - Ethics in Special, Complex and Irregular Military Operations","description":"

“Conventional” military operations, in which the uniformed military forces of one state engage with an equivalent force of another state, have become the exception rather than the norm in contemporary warfare. Instead, military forces now more often find themselves pitted against non-state (or hybrid) opponents who avoid symmetric military engagements, preferring to seek shelter among civilian populations while employing a range of asymmetric guerrilla and terrorist tactics in operations located in the 'grey zone' between war and peace. States are making increasing use of special operations forces and other unconventional capabilities (such as cyber/information warfare operations) to carry out 'grey zone' missions which raise new ethical challenges, and those same special operations forces find themselves fighting alongside and enabling irregular and non-state forces which employ a mode of warfare that is distinctly unconventional. Conventional units  are obliged to negotiate the complexities associated with fighting on urban terrain, managing refugees, cooperating with coalition partners, managing relationships with surrogate forces, gaining the trust of local tribes, contending with host nation group rivalries, resolving cultural tensions and building a stable and lasting peace.


These obligations considerably complicate the existing challenges of conducting operations in a manner consistent with the legal, ethical and social norms for the use of military force. Military leaders must, therefore, be conversant with the relevant moral conventions and ethical principles associated with armed conflict, and must be familiar with the decision-making techniques needed to apply them in a way that will enable success in complex environments.  This course addresses the context in which special operations, complex operations and irregular warfare are conducted. Course material draws on insights from the study of applied ethics, moral philosophy, moral psychology and related disciplines with a focus on enhancing and extending the practice of ethical leadership.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ZHSS8463","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8463 - International Law in Global Politics","description":"

International law plays an integral role in the system of international politics: the rules-based global order. This course challenges students to analyse that role and the major interpretations of that role in an era when rising and revisionist powers may be re-shaping the rules-based order.


The content covered includes topics such as: the core principles and concepts of international law; international law and the use of military force; the role of multilateral treaties in global governance; distinguishing a political from a legal interpretation of a multilateral treaty; the operation of international courts and tribunals; and the relationship between foreign policy formulation and international law with an emphasis on current case studies such as the shifting balance of power in the South China Sea.


This is an International Relations course focusing on the interaction of law and politics. It is not a Law course so no prior knowledge of international law is required.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2bd8e9fbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961915","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Drawing on the material covered in the course, and further independent research, students are required to write a 2,500 word research essay. Students will be provided with a topic drawn from the course content.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"27d8a9fbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"63d8a9fbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6fd8a9fbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ea","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"abd8a9fbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e7d8a9fbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"17d8a9fbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Discussion Forum Participation and Reflective Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will be required to make regular contributions to the directed discussions on the course discussion forum. At the end of the semester they will be required to submit their 4 best comments, and a reflective journal (up to 1,250 words total) about what they learned from interacting with their classmates through the discussion forum and how their thinking about the role of international law in world politics has changed throughout the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"27d8a9fbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"63d8a9fbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"afd8a9fbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5fd8a9fbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619dc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Short Answer Papers","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Over the duration of the course students are required to write three brief (indicatively 500 word) analyses explaining key concepts in the course and their application to contemporary case studies of the interplay of international law and politics.

One such paper will be a draft outline for the research paper.

The remaining two analysis papers (500 words each) will be short answer tests on the various set readings or viewings and listed treaties.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"27d8a9fbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"63d8a9fbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6fd8a9fbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ea","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"abd8a9fbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"97d8a9fbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e1","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZHSS8463.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

International law plays an integral role in the system of international politics: the rules-based global order. This course challenges students to analyse that role and the major interpretations of that role in an era when rising and revisionist powers may be re-shaping the rules-based order.

The content covered includes topics such as: the core principles and concepts of international law; international law and the use of military force; the role of multilateral treaties in global governance; distinguishing a political from a legal interpretation of a multilateral treaty; the operation of international courts and tribunals; and the relationship between foreign policy formulation and international law with an emphasis on current case studies such as the shifting balance of power in the South China Sea.

This is an International Relations course focusing on the interaction of law and politics. It is not a Law course so no prior knowledge of international law is required.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ZHSS8464","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8464 - Cyberspace, National Security and Law","description":"

How law applies to the cyber domain is presenting increasingly acute challenges for security and military perspectives. From a military perspective, cyber is now a fundamental component of physical operational domains of sea, land, air, and space. From a security perspective, the cyber domain and cyber capabilities also present democracies with significant challenges in balancing the imperatives of security with the protection and maintenance of human rights such as privacy. This course will examine the current state of the ‘law’ – both international and domestic – as it relates to cyber as a military and security capability

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ZHSS8467","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8467 - Military Game Changers in 21st Century Warfare","description":"

While the nature of war does not change, the character of war unquestionably does. During this course we explore four key disruptive capabilities changing the character of 21st Century warfare: special operations, cyber war, autonomous weapons systems and space operations. After learning the basics of each capability we will look at its impact on operational and tactical levels of the military, as well as discuss implications for international relations and the law and finally, the ethical considerations. The course will require students to hypothesise how these capabilities will combine and interact in potential future conflict.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0315953bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961982","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Drawing on material covered in the course and further independent research, students will write a 3,000 word research essay. Each student will develop their own research question based on personal interests and field of employment. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0715953bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8b15953bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961978","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c715953bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96197b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ba15953bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961918","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Analysis Papers - peer review","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

For each of the four course topics, students will write a short (approx. 400 - 500 word) analysis paper addressing key ideas and concepts covered in that topic. As a peer review exercise, following guidelines, each student will then review 1 other student’s paper. Each student’s original submission and review will be graded and worth equal marks, 5%. For a total of 10% per topic.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4f15953bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961975","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8b15953bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961978","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c715953bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96197b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ba15953bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961929","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

For each topic (cyber, special operations, space operations and autonomous weapons/AI) students are required to pass a 10 question quiz. Students will have two opportunities to pass the quiz. Each quiz will be worth 5% of the final grade.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ZHSS8501","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8501 - Principles of Public Leadership","description":"

Public leadership is differentiated from other forms of leadership in that its principal focus is promoting the common good and pursuing the public interest. In brief, it is leadership that does not seek to preference or prejudice the needs or desires of any group at the expense of others or to advance personal or private aspirations and objectives to the detriment of the collective wellbeing of the entire citizenry. Public leadership is indifferent to polemical agendas and partisan goals, and transcends the practical preoccupations of administration and management. This course begins with interpretations of competing and contrasting definitions of the ‘public’; provides a basis for identifying and then differentiating ‘leadership’ from oversight, supervision and management; canvasses the elements and imperatives of reliable and responsible leadership; and, offers students a template for describing the possible objectives and outcomes of ‘public leadership’ in a range of professional settings. While the focus will be on research into general principles, the student will be encouraged to consider these principles within the circumstances of their own organization and in the context of Australia’s evolving public life. The course provides a theoretical foundation for the exercise of effective public leadership.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"286d74bbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961902","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Analysis Paper 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Drawing on a previous or present workplace experience, produce a statement of i) who, where or what constitutes the public to be served by that workplace, ii) how the public interest is described in legislation and regulation, policies or procedures, and iii) the expectations imposed on leaders to advance the public interest. 1500 words.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"186d34bbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"506d34bbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"646d34bbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9c6d34bbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d86d34bbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"086d34bbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Analysis Paper 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Critically review four chapters from the prescribed text (min. 500 words for each chapter) addressing i) where you found this chapter has enriched your understanding of the principles of public leadership, ii) could enhance your practice of public leadership, and iii) where you disagreed with its conclusions or prescriptions. 1500 words.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"186d34bbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"506d34bbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"646d34bbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9c6d34bbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d86d34bbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"406d34bbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Analysis Paper 3","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Choose one of the following options:

a. Identify and assess the expectations of superiors, subordinates and stakeholders of leaders in your previous or present workplace.

b. Assess duty statements, contractual obligations or statutory responsibilities that require the exercise of leadership including mechanisms for its evaluation in your previous or present workplace.

c. “The organisation needs leaders but employs them as managers”. Discuss this statement with respect to your previous or present workplace and account for the tension between leadership and management, including formal and informal impediments or restrictions on the exercise of Leadership.

contentlets.keywords: humanities & social sciences,public policy,leadership,ethics
contentlets.description: Public leadership is differentiated from other forms of leadership in that its principal focus is promoting the common good and pursuing the public interest. In brief, it is leadership that does not seek to preference or prejudice the needs or desires of any group at the expense of others or to advance personal or private aspirations and objectives to the detriment of the collective wellbeing of the entire citizenry. Public leadership is indifferent to polemical agendas and partisan goals, and transcends the practical preoccupations of administration and management. This course begins with interpretations of competing and contrasting definitions of the ‘public’; provides a basis for identifying and then differentiating ‘leadership’ from oversight, supervision and management; canvasses the elements and imperatives of reliable and responsible leadership; and, offers students a template for describing the possible objectives and outcomes of ‘public leadership’ in a range of professional settings. While the focus will be on research into general principles, the student will be encouraged to consider these principles within the circumstances of their own organization and in the context of Australia’s evolving public life. The course provides a theoretical foundation for the exercise of effective public leadership.
contentlets.title: Principles of Public Leadership

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8503 - Moral Leadership in Complex Military Operations","description":"

“Conventional” military operations, in which the uniformed military forces of one state engage with an equivalent force of another state, have become the exception rather than the norm in contemporary warfare. Instead, military forces now more often find themselves pitted against non-state (or hybrid) opponents who avoid symmetric military engagements, preferring to seek shelter among civilian populations while employing a range of asymmetric guerrilla and terrorist tactics in operations located in the 'grey zone' between war and peace. For their part, national forces are obliged to negotiate the complexities associated with of fighting on urban terrain, managing refugees, cooperating with coalition partners, managing relationships with surrogate forces, gaining the trust of local tribes, contending with host nation group rivalries, resolving cultural tensions and building a stable and lasting peace.


 


These obligations considerably complicate the existing challenges of conducting operations in a manner consistent with the legal, ethical and social norms for the use of military force. Military leaders must, therefore, be conversant with the relevant moral conventions and ethical principles associated with armed conflict and familiar with the decision-making techniques needed to apply them in a way that will enable success in complex environments. Leaders must concurrently be acquainted with the gap between the individual moral frameworks found in multi-cultural liberal democratic societies and the international treaties and domestic laws that regulate the use of military force. This course addresses the context in which complex operations are conducted, the issues associated with using force in complicated socio-political and religious environments, and the demands this context and these issues impose on uniformed leadership. Course material draws on insights from the study of applied ethics, moral philosophy, moral psychology and related disciplines with a focus on enhancing and extending the practice of leadership.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"dff105b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b7","name":"Fully online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Syndicate Papers","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Over the duration of the intensive component of the course students will participate in a number of syndicate discussions which culminate in a twopart exercise. Students will be required to individually write two analytical papers of 1000 words, each addressing the key analytical challenges of, respectively, parts one and parts two of the exercise. Further information on the syndicate exercise and the papers will be given at the onset of the intensive component of the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1ff105b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5bf105b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"83f105b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dff105b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961992","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7af105b7db391c50eb6b147a3a96197d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Drawing on the material covered in the course, and further independent research, students are required to write a 3,000-word research essay. Students will be provided with a list of topics drawn from the course content.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1ff105b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5bf105b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"83f105b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dff105b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961992","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"83f105b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961982","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

All students are expected to both contribute to the success of the course and to engage and learn from all of its aspects. At the end of the course each student will be asked to package together his or her five best forum contributions (addressing five separate topics), reflect on them and give them a little context. Each student will be assessed on the level of engagement with and understanding of the topics; the engagement with and responses to questions raised (and his or her own raising of questions); and reflections on his or her own learning and intellectual development. Obviously, the preparation for this assignment involves students doing the required reading for each topic, forming questions, and regularly making quality contributions in the forums. Please remember quality matters. Brief question raising and direct on-the-point posts are usually preferable to longer more verbose posts (maximum post length is 200 words).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1ff105b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"83f105b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"97f105b7db391c50eb6b147a3a96199b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cbf105b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961986","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZHSS8503.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ZHSS8504","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZHSS8504 - Space Cooperation, Conflict and Competition","description":"

The exploration and use of the space domain was born out of great power competition and under the spectre of conflict between the USSR and the US. Yet, over the early decades after the dawn of the space age, exploration of outer space was often characterised by cooperation. In the last decade, an increasing number of States, non-State and commercial actors have sought to exploit the commercial, strategic and scientific opportunities of this domain. Sometimes they cooperate, often they compete, and the spectre of conflict in space itself looms larger than it ever has. Under-regulated conflict and competition risks making Earth orbits and beyond unusable in the near future and for generations to come, with potentially devastating consequences on Earth. This course aims to introduce students to these challenges and to the physical, historical, commercial, strategic, political, legal and ethical contexts in which these challenges must be managed. It seeks to enable students to navigate, and help others to navigate, those contexts to achieve their objectives (and those of their organisations) and be valuable participants in the sustainable use and exploration of outer space.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c19c31621bbd2410d5fb0fabdc4bcb07","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Reflective Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Weekly journal entries of approximately 250 words in Weeks 2 to 11, each worth 5% of the course total. Entries involve reflection on course content, real world news, Q&A sessions and wargame scenario news, and their relationship to Course Learning Outcomes, all within the student’s own context.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c19c31621bbd2410d5fb0fabdc4bcb08","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c59c31621bbd2410d5fb0fabdc4bcb09","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cd9c31621bbd2410d5fb0fabdc4bcb08","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cd9c31621bbd2410d5fb0fabdc4bcb09","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"499c31621bbd2410d5fb0fabdc4bcbff","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This 2000 word essay is the culmination of the course. It is due in Week 14 of the course. Substantive content will be delivered in Weeks 2 to 11 inclusive and Weeks 12 to 14 inclusive will be for essay writing. Students will select from a number of specified essay questions, each of which is designed to cover all CLOs.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c19c31621bbd2410d5fb0fabdc4bcb08","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c59c31621bbd2410d5fb0fabdc4bcb09","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cd9c31621bbd2410d5fb0fabdc4bcb08","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cd9c31621bbd2410d5fb0fabdc4bcb09","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"859c31621bbd2410d5fb0fabdc4bcb0b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Outline of essay and annotated bibliography","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

This second assessment is a precursor to the essay - the third assessment. The students must write 500 words providing an outline for the essay and an annotated bibliography of major reference sources for the essay. This is due during the mid-semester break, after 5 of the 10 substantive weeks of course content, giving the students a good opportunity to consider the upcoming essay.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c19c31621bbd2410d5fb0fabdc4bcb08","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c59c31621bbd2410d5fb0fabdc4bcb09","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cd9c31621bbd2410d5fb0fabdc4bcb08","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cd9c31621bbd2410d5fb0fabdc4bcb09","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"919c71621bbd2410d5fb0fabdc4bcb04","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZHSS8504.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
